But the constant intercourse with Him who was full of grace and truth, in childhood as in manhood, must have prepared J ames to find in the Ten Commandments no mere outward regulations, but an inner law of liberty and love written in the heart. That deep interest in the mysteries of the kingdom, that earnest search after truth which led the child J esus to romain behind in thetemple, both listening to the doctors and asking 1116111 questions, must surely have had its effect upon his brother. Whatever means of instruction were within reach of the home at Nazareth would, we may feel certain, have been eagerly taken ad- vantage of by all its inmates. While accepting, therefore, the view which seems to be best supported, that J esus and his brothers usually spoke Aramaic, we are surely not bound to suppose that with towns like Sepphoris and Tiberias in their immediate vicinity, with Ptolemais, Scythopolis} and Gadara at no great distance, they remained ignorant of Greek.
